title: Engine Rough Idle or Shaking When Stopped
symptom_short: Rough idle or shaking when stopped
symptom_patterns: engine feels like it will stall

likely_causes.cause: Dirty or failing spark plugs
likely_causes.notes: Common on high-mileage engines or if maintenance is overdue.

likely_causes.cause: Clogged fuel injector
likely_causes.notes: May be worse when engine is cold.

likely_causes.cause: Vacuum leak (cracked hose or gasket)
likely_causes.notes: Can eventually trigger check-engine light and poor fuel economy.

recommended_checks: Check maintenance history for last spark-plug change.
Listen for hissing sounds around intake hoses.
Scan for misfire or fuel-trim codes with an OBD-II scanner.
safety_warning: Avoid hard acceleration until the misfire cause is identified. Severe misfires can damage the catalytic converter.

title: Flashing Check-Engine Light Under Load
symptom_short: Flashing check-engine light under load

likely_causes.cause: Severe engine misfire
likely_causes.notes: Unburned fuel can overheat and destroy the catalytic converter.

likely_causes.cause: Ignition coil failure
likely_causes.notes: Often happens under heavy load or uphill driving.

recommended_checks: If the light is flashing, reduce speed and avoid hard acceleration.
If the flashing continues, safely pull over and shut off the engine.
Scan for misfire codes (e.g., P0300–P0306).
safety_warning: A flashing check-engine light usually means STOP DRIVING soon. Continuing to drive can cause very expensive damage.

title: Hard Starting When Engine Is Cold
symptom_short: Hard starting when engine is cold

likely_causes.cause: Weak battery or poor battery connections
Failing coolant-temperature sensor
Fuel system issue (weak pump or leaking injector)

recommended_checks: Check battery age and look for corrosion on terminals.
Notice if the problem is only on cold mornings or always.
Listen for fuel-pump prime sound when turning key to ON.
safety_warning: If the engine cranks very slowly, avoid repeated attempts that overheat the starter and cables.

title: Engine Overheating in Traffic but OK at Highway Speed
symptom_short: Engine overheating in traffic but OK at highway speed

likely_causes.cause: Cooling fan not working (electric fan or clutch fan)
Restricted radiator fins (bugs, debris)

recommended_checks: With engine cool, visually check radiator and condenser for blockage.
With AC on and engine warm, verify if cooling fans turn on.
Watch temperature gauge; if it enters red zone, shut engine off safely.
safety_warning: Do not continue driving an overheating engine. Severe overheating can warp the cylinder head and cause head-gasket failure.

title: Engine Overheating Mainly at Highway Speeds
symptom_short: Engine overheating mainly at highway speeds

likely_causes.cause: Low coolant or coolant leak
Partially clogged radiator
Failing water pump

recommended_checks: With engine cool, check coolant level in reservoir.
Look for dried coolant traces around hoses, radiator, and water pump.
Observe for sweet smell or steam from engine bay.
safety_warning: Never open the radiator cap while the engine is hot. Hot coolant can spray and cause serious burns.

title: No Heat from Cabin Vents but Engine Warm
symptom_short: No heat from cabin vents but engine reaches normal temp

likely_causes.cause: Low coolant level
Clogged heater core
Air trapped in cooling system

recommended_checks: Check coolant level when engine is cold.
Note if windshield fogs with sweet smell (may indicate heater-core leak).
Check if both heater hoses in engine bay feel warm when engine is hot.
safety_warning: Coolant leaks that affect the heater can eventually lead to engine overheating if ignored.

title: High-Pitched Squeal When Braking at Low Speed
symptom_short: High-pitched squeal when braking at low speed

likely_causes.cause: Brake wear indicator contacting rotor (pads near end of life)
Glazed pads or rotors
Dust or rust on rotor surface after sitting

recommended_checks: Notice if noise happens only first few stops of the day or always.
Check for visible pad thickness through wheel spokes if possible.
Have a technician inspect pad and rotor condition.
safety_warning: If the squeal turns into a grinding or scraping sound, stop driving — you may be down to metal-on-metal brakes.

title: Grinding or Scraping Noise When Braking
symptom_short: Grinding or scraping noise when braking

likely_causes.cause: Pads worn through to metal backing plate
Stuck caliper or hardware

recommended_checks: Avoid driving except to move the car to a safe location.
Have brakes inspected as soon as possible.
Check for brake warning lights on dashboard.
safety_warning: Driving with grinding brakes is unsafe and can cause rotor failure and loss of braking ability.

title: Soft or Spongy Brake Pedal
symptom_short: Soft or spongy brake pedal

likely_causes.cause: Air in brake lines
Brake fluid leak
Failing master cylinder

recommended_checks: Press and hold the brake pedal at a stop; note if it slowly sinks.
Look for fluid leaks near wheels or under brake master cylinder.
Do not continue driving if braking ability is reduced.
safety_warning: A soft pedal can mean imminent brake failure. Tow the vehicle rather than driving it.

title: ABS Warning Light Stays On
symptom_short: ABS warning light stays on

likely_causes.cause: Faulty wheel speed sensor
Damaged tone ring or wiring
ABS module fault

recommended_checks: Note if ABS activates too early or not at all on hard braking.
Scan ABS system for codes using capable scanner.
Inspect wheel-speed sensor wiring near wheels for damage.
safety_warning: Conventional braking usually still works, but anti-lock function may be disabled. Increase following distance on wet or slippery roads.

title: Tire Pressure Warning (TPMS) Light On
symptom_short: Tire pressure warning (TPMS) light on

likely_causes.cause: Low tire pressure in one or more tires
TPMS sensor battery low or failed

recommended_checks: Check tire pressure with a gauge; fill to door-jamb specification.
Inspect tires for nails, screws, or visible damage.
If pressures are OK but light stays on, have sensors checked.
safety_warning: Driving on an under-inflated tire can cause overheating, poor handling, and potential blowout.

title: Vibration at Highway Speeds
symptom_short: Vibration in steering wheel or seat at highway speeds

likely_causes.cause: Wheel balance issue
Uneven tire wear or belt separation
Bent wheel or suspension component

recommended_checks: Note the speed range where vibration is worst.
Check tires visually for bulges, flat spots, or exposed cords.
Have wheels balanced and alignment checked.
safety_warning: Severe tire defects can lead to blowouts at speed. Reduce speed and inspect tires if vibration is strong or sudden.

title: Clunking Noise Over Bumps at Low Speed
symptom_short: Clunking noise over bumps at low speed

likely_causes.cause: Worn stabilizer bar (sway bar) links or bushings
Loose strut mount or worn strut
Control arm bushing wear

recommended_checks: Note if the sound is from front, rear, or one side only.
Check if noise is louder when turning and going over bumps.
Have suspension inspected on a lift.
safety_warning: Severely worn suspension parts can affect steering control, especially during emergency maneuvers.

title: Squeaking Suspension at Low Speed
symptom_short: Squeaking suspension at low speed or entering driveway

likely_causes.cause: Dry control-arm or sway-bar bushings
Worn ball joints

recommended_checks: Notice if sound changes with temperature or rain.
Check if squeak occurs while steering, braking, or only with body motion.
Schedule suspension inspection if persistent.
safety_warning: While often not immediately dangerous, squeaks can be an early sign of wear that later affects steering safety.

title: Car Pulls to One Side While Driving Straight
symptom_short: Car pulls to one side while driving straight

likely_causes.cause: Incorrect wheel alignment
Uneven tire pressure
Brake caliper sticking on one wheel

recommended_checks: Check tire pressures and adjust to spec.
Notice if wheel or brake on one side feels hotter after driving.
Schedule alignment check if pull persists.
safety_warning: Severe pulling, especially under braking, can affect your ability to keep the car in its lane.

title: Loose Feeling or Play in Steering Wheel
symptom_short: Loose feeling or play in steering wheel

likely_causes.cause: Worn tie-rod ends or steering rack components
Worn steering shaft joints
Improper alignment or worn suspension bushings

recommended_checks: Note if steering response feels delayed when turning.
Observe if car wanders and needs constant correction on highway.
Have steering and suspension checked on a lift.
safety_warning: Serious steering looseness is a safety hazard and can lead to loss of control, especially at speed.

title: Whining Noise That Changes with Vehicle Speed
symptom_short: Whining noise that changes with vehicle speed

likely_causes.cause: Worn differential or gearset
Wheel bearing wear
Tire pattern noise

recommended_checks: Note if noise changes when turning left or right.
Observe if pitch changes with throttle on/off or only with speed.
Have wheel bearings and differential fluid checked.
safety_warning: Severely worn bearings or gears can overheat and seize, potentially causing loss of control.

title: Clicking or Popping When Turning at Low Speed
symptom_short: Clicking or popping when turning at low speed

likely_causes.cause: Outer CV joint wear on front-wheel-drive or AWD
Loose axle nut or suspension component

recommended_checks: Notice if sound is louder on full lock turns and during acceleration.
Determine if noise comes from one front corner.
Inspect CV boots for tears or missing grease.
safety_warning: Severely worn CV joints can eventually fail and leave the vehicle without drive.

title: Battery/Charging Light On While Driving
symptom_short: Battery/charging light on while driving

likely_causes.cause: Alternator not charging properly
Loose or slipping serpentine belt
Corroded battery terminals or cables

recommended_checks: Turn off non-essential electrical loads (AC, heated seats, rear defrost).
Notice if lights dim or blower slows down.
Have charging system tested as soon as possible.
safety_warning: Once the battery is depleted, the engine may stall suddenly. Avoid long trips and night driving until fixed.

title: Headlights Dim at Idle but Brighten When Revving
symptom_short: Headlights dim at idle but brighten when revving

likely_causes.cause: Weak alternator output at low RPM
High electrical load at idle (AC, defrost, audio)
Loose or corroded grounds

recommended_checks: Observe if dimming is worse with AC or rear defrost on.
Check battery age and condition.
Ask for charging-system and ground-circuit inspection.
safety_warning: Severe dimming or flickering can precede alternator failure, which may stall the engine while driving.

title: Clicking, Engine Does Not Crank
symptom_short: Single click or rapid clicking, engine does not crank
symptom_patterns: rapid click sound from engine bay

likely_causes.cause: Weak or discharged battery
Loose or corroded battery terminals
Failing starter motor or solenoid

recommended_checks: Check if interior lights are dim or go out when trying to start.
Inspect battery terminals for white/green corrosion.
Note if problem is worse after car sits overnight.
safety_warning: Repeated attempts to crank with a weak battery can overheat cables and the starter. Avoid cranking for more than 10 seconds at a time.

title: Battery Repeatedly Dies After Sitting Overnight
symptom_short: Battery repeatedly dies after sitting overnight

likely_causes.cause: Parasitic electrical draw from module, light, or accessory staying on
likely_causes.notes: Common causes include glovebox, trunk lights, aftermarket alarms, or radios.

likely_causes.cause: Battery at end of life and unable to hold charge
likely_causes.notes: Batteries typically last 3–5 years depending on climate.

recommended_checks: Check battery age and have it load-tested.
After shutting car off, verify that all interior and trunk lights go out.
Have a technician measure key-off current draw with an ammeter.
safety_warning: Frequent jump-starting can damage electronics and leave you stranded in unsafe locations.

title: Engine Suddenly Shuts Off While Driving
symptom_short: Engine suddenly shuts off while driving, then may restart

likely_causes.cause: Intermittent crankshaft or camshaft position sensor failure
likely_causes.notes: Often stalls when hot and may restart after cooling.

likely_causes.cause: Main power or ground connection loose (battery or engine ground strap)
likely_causes.notes: Can also cause multiple warning lights and random resets.

likely_causes.cause: Failing engine control module power relay

recommended_checks: Notice if dash lights also go out when the engine dies or stay on.
Gently wiggle battery cables (engine off) and inspect for corrosion or looseness.
Scan for stored fault codes even if lights are currently off.
safety_warning: Sudden loss of power steering and brake assist can make the car difficult to control. Pull over safely as soon as it is safe if the engine stalls repeatedly.

title: Strong Burning Plastic or Electrical Smell Inside Cabin
symptom_short: Strong burning plastic or electrical smell inside cabin

likely_causes.cause: Overheated wiring, connector, or blower-motor resistor
likely_causes.notes: Often related to HVAC fan speeds or aftermarket accessories.

likely_causes.cause: Short circuit in seat heaters, window circuits, or steering column

recommended_checks: Turn off recently used accessories (seat heaters, rear defrost, phone chargers) and see if smell changes.
Do not ignore visible smoke or melted plastic around switches or vents.
Have wiring inspected before continuing to use the affected circuit.
safety_warning: A strong electrical burning smell or visible smoke can precede an interior fire. Safely stop the vehicle, turn it off, and exit if the smell is intense or smoke is visible.

title: Main Fuse or Large Fuse Blows Repeatedly
symptom_short: Main fuse or large fuse blows repeatedly
symptom_patterns: replace fuse and it blows again

likely_causes.cause: Direct short to ground in a high-current circuit (starter, alternator, or main power feed)
likely_causes.notes: Replacing the fuse without fixing the underlying problem can cause further damage.

recommended_checks: Do not keep installing larger or multiple fuses; this is unsafe.
Note which systems stop working when the fuse blows (charging, interior power, etc.).
Have a qualified technician diagnose the short with proper equipment.
safety_warning: High-current shorts can overheat wiring and start a fire. The vehicle should not be driven until the cause is found and repaired.

title: AC Blows Warm Air Instead of Cold
symptom_short: AC blows warm or only slightly cool air

likely_causes.cause: Low refrigerant charge from small leak
Condenser or radiator fans not operating correctly
Blend-door or control issue inside HVAC box

recommended_checks: Note if AC is colder at highway speed than at idle.
Listen for condenser fan operation when AC is on and car is stopped.
Check if AC becomes warm when climbing hills or when engine warms up.
safety_warning: AC performance issues are usually not immediately dangerous, but lack of cooling can contribute to driver fatigue in extreme heat.

title: Strong Fuel Smell Around Car or Inside Cabin
symptom_short: Strong fuel smell around car or inside cabin
symptom_patterns: gas smell near rear of car

likely_causes.cause: Fuel leak at lines, injectors, or tank area
Evaporative emissions (EVAP) system leak or loose gas cap

recommended_checks: Do not smoke or use open flame near a car with fuel smell.
Check that gas cap is tight and in good condition.
Look under car for wet spots or drips when parked.
safety_warning: Fuel leaks can cause fire or explosion, especially in enclosed spaces like garages. If smell is strong, avoid driving and have the car inspected.

title: Water on Floor or Wet Carpets Inside Car
symptom_short: Water on floor or wet carpets inside car

likely_causes.cause: Clogged sunroof or cowl drains
Blocked AC evaporator drain causing condensate to leak inside
Door or window seal leak

recommended_checks: Note if water appears after rain, car wash, or AC use.
Check for visible dripping near passenger footwell when AC is running.
Dry carpets as soon as possible to avoid mold and odor.
safety_warning: While not usually a direct safety issue, long-term moisture can damage electronics under the carpet and cause mold growth harmful to occupants.

title: Loud Exhaust or Rumble Under Car
symptom_short: Loud exhaust or rumble under car

likely_causes.cause: Hole or crack in exhaust pipe, muffler, or flex pipe
Broken exhaust hanger causing pipe to touch body

recommended_checks: Note if sound is louder on acceleration or cold start.
Listen near center and rear of car (from safe distance) for leakage.
Avoid idling in enclosed spaces due to exhaust fumes.
safety_warning: Exhaust leaks under the car can allow carbon monoxide into the cabin, especially with windows closed.

title: Rotten-Egg or Sulfur Smell from Exhaust
symptom_short: Rotten-egg or sulfur smell from exhaust

likely_causes.cause: Catalytic converter overheating or failing
Rich fuel mixture causing excess sulfur compounds

recommended_checks: Note if smell occurs mostly after hard acceleration or long hill climbs.
Check for recent misfire, rough running, or poor fuel economy.
Scan for emissions-related fault codes.
safety_warning: A failing catalytic converter can eventually plug and restrict exhaust flow, causing loss of power and potential engine damage.

title: Excessive Smoke from Exhaust
symptom_short: Excessive smoke from exhaust (blue, white, or black)

likely_causes.cause: Blue smoke: burning engine oil (worn piston rings, valve seals, or turbo)
White sweet-smelling smoke that lasts: coolant entering combustion (head gasket leak)
Black smoke: overly rich fuel mixture (fuel or sensor problems)

recommended_checks: Observe smoke color, smell, and when it appears (start-up, acceleration, idle).
Check coolant and oil levels frequently if smoke is new.
Avoid long trips until cause is identified.
safety_warning: Coolant or fuel-related smoke can quickly lead to engine damage or catalytic-converter failure. Stop driving if temperature rises or if power drops sharply.

title: Pinging or Knocking Noise on Acceleration
symptom_short: Pinging or knocking noise on acceleration

likely_causes.cause: Low octane fuel for the engine's requirement
Carbon buildup in combustion chamber
Faulty knock sensor or ignition timing issue

recommended_checks: Note if noise is worse on hot days or under heavy load.
Try one tank of higher-octane fuel if the car specifies premium.
Scan for knock-sensor or timing-related fault codes.
safety_warning: Persistent heavy knocking can damage pistons and bearings. Avoid hard acceleration until the issue is resolved.

title: Oil Pressure Warning Light Flickers at Idle
symptom_short: Oil pressure warning light flickers at idle but goes off with revs

likely_causes.cause: Low engine oil level or thin/old oil
Worn engine bearings reducing oil pressure
Faulty oil pressure sensor (after confirming oil level & condition)

recommended_checks: Check engine oil level as soon as possible on level ground.
Listen for ticking or knocking noises from engine when hot.
Have mechanical oil pressure tested if light persists.
safety_warning: Driving with low oil pressure can destroy an engine quickly. If the light stays on solid, shut the engine off immediately.

title: Engine Cranks but Does Not Start
symptom_short: Engine cranks strongly but does not start
symptom_patterns: engine turns over but won't start

likely_causes.cause: No fuel delivery (failed pump, relay, or clogged filter)
No spark (failed crank sensor, ignition coil, or module)
Security/immobilizer preventing start

recommended_checks: Note if there is fuel smell from exhaust after repeated cranking.
Check if security light is flashing or message appears in cluster.
Listen for fuel-pump priming sound when key is turned to ON.
safety_warning: Avoid extended cranking; it can flood the engine or overheat the starter and cables.

title: Loud Knocking from Engine with Low Oil Level
symptom_short: Loud knocking from engine with low oil level
symptom_patterns: engine knocking gets worse with RPM

likely_causes.cause: Severe bearing damage from oil starvation

recommended_checks: Check oil level immediately and do not drive if extremely low or empty.
Notice if knock started after oil-change neglect or leak.
Tow vehicle to a shop; internal repair or engine replacement may be required.
safety_warning: Continuing to run a knocking engine can lead to catastrophic failure, seizure, or broken connecting rods exiting the engine block.

title: Engine Overheat with Steam or White Vapor from Under Hood
symptom_short: Engine overheats and steam or white vapor comes from under hood

likely_causes.cause: Major coolant leak or hose rupture
Radiator cap failure causing boil-over

recommended_checks: Safely pull over and shut engine off immediately.
Do not open hood until steam subsides.
Do not open radiator cap when hot; wait until fully cooled.
safety_warning: Severe overheating can cause head-gasket failure and engine damage within minutes. Towing is strongly recommended.

title: High-Voltage Isolation Fault in Hybrid/EV
symptom_short: Hybrid/EV shows high-voltage isolation fault or service HV system message
symptom_patterns: ev ready light off with hv warning

likely_causes.cause: Moisture intrusion into high-voltage components or wiring
Insulation damage on HV cables or battery pack

recommended_checks: Do not attempt to service high-voltage components yourself.
Note if warning appears after heavy rain, flooding, or car wash.
Have vehicle inspected by a qualified hybrid/EV technician.
safety_warning: High-voltage systems can be lethal. Only trained technicians with proper protective equipment should diagnose HV isolation issues.

title: Harsh or Jerky Shifts Between Gears
symptom_short: Harsh, jerky, or delayed shifts between gears

likely_causes.cause: Low or degraded transmission fluid
likely_causes.notes: Especially common if fluid service has been neglected.

likely_causes.cause: Valve body or shift solenoid issues
likely_causes.notes: May trigger transmission-related fault codes.

likely_causes.cause: Outdated or corrupted transmission control software
likely_causes.notes: Some vehicles require TCM software updates.

recommended_checks: Verify transmission fluid level and condition (color, smell).
Note if harsh shifts are worse when cold or after long drives.
Scan the transmission module for stored fault codes.
safety_warning: Prolonged harsh shifting can accelerate internal wear and lead to expensive transmission failure.

title: Engine RPM Flares but Vehicle Does Not Accelerate
symptom_short: Engine revs up but speed increases slowly

likely_causes.cause: Worn clutches or bands inside automatic transmission
Low transmission fluid due to leak
Failing torque converter

recommended_checks: Check for red or brown fluid leaks under vehicle.
Note if slipping occurs only in certain gears or all the time.
Avoid towing or heavy acceleration until the issue is diagnosed.
safety_warning: Severe transmission slip can suddenly leave the car without drive, especially during passing or merging.

title: No Reverse Gear or Very Weak Reverse
symptom_short: Reverse gear does not engage or is very weak

likely_causes.cause: Internal transmission damage to reverse clutch or gearset
Shifter cable or linkage misadjustment

recommended_checks: Confirm that shifter indicator matches the actual gear position.
Note if reverse worked intermittently before failing completely.
Have transmission operation tested by a specialist.
safety_warning: Lack of reverse gear can be dangerous in tight spaces or on slopes. Avoid parking where reverse is required to exit.

title: Delay When Shifting into Drive or Reverse
symptom_short: Delay or hesitation when shifting from Park to Drive/Reverse

likely_causes.cause: Low or aerated transmission fluid
Internal wear in clutch packs or seals

recommended_checks: Check fluid level with manufacturer procedure.
Note if delay is worse cold or hot.
Listen for abnormal noises when gear finally engages.
safety_warning: Long delays can precede more serious transmission failure. Avoid aggressive throttle when gear first engages.

title: Binding or Hopping in Tight Turns (AWD/4x4)
symptom_short: Vehicle feels like it hops or binds on tight turns

likely_causes.cause: Part-time 4x4 engaged on dry pavement
likely_causes.notes: Many 4x4 systems are intended for loose surfaces only.

likely_causes.cause: Worn or contaminated fluid in AWD coupling or differential

recommended_checks: Verify transfer case mode (2H, 4H, 4L, Auto).
Disengage 4x4 on dry pavement and re-test.
Service differential and transfer case fluids if due.
safety_warning: Driving a part-time 4x4 on high-grip pavement can damage driveline components and affect handling.

title: Service 4WD or AWD Warning
symptom_short: Service 4WD/AWD message or light

likely_causes.cause: Fault in transfer case motor, sensor, or control module
Wheel-speed sensor issues affecting AWD control

recommended_checks: Note if 4WD modes engage or if only 2WD is available.
Scan for drivetrain and ABS-related codes.
Avoid off-road conditions requiring 4x4 until repaired.
safety_warning: Loss of AWD/4WD can reduce traction on snow, mud, or steep terrain. Plan driving accordingly.

title: Diesel DPF Regenerations Very Frequent
symptom_short: Diesel particulate filter (DPF) regenerations happen very often

likely_causes.cause: Short-trip driving that never allows full regeneration
Driving with failing sensors (exhaust temperature, pressure) or injectors causing excess soot

recommended_checks: Perform a continuous highway drive to allow complete regen if safe.
Check for diesel fault codes related to DPF or exhaust sensors.
Avoid interrupting regeneration cycles when possible.
safety_warning: Ignoring DPF warnings can lead to restricted exhaust and limp mode, and may require expensive filter replacement.

title: Glow Plug Light Flashing While Driving
symptom_short: Diesel glow plug or coil-like light flashes

likely_causes.cause: Injection or emissions system fault on diesel engine

recommended_checks: Note any loss of power or limp mode.
Scan engine for diesel-specific fault codes.
Avoid heavy loads or towing until diagnosed.
safety_warning: Some diesel faults can cause severe internal or emissions-system damage if ignored.

title: Hybrid/EV Shows Noticeably Reduced Electric Range
symptom_short: Hybrid or EV has much lower EV range than usual

likely_causes.cause: Battery capacity loss due to age and cycles
Cold weather reducing effective capacity
Tire pressure low or rolling resistance increased

recommended_checks: Compare range under similar temperature and driving style.
Check tire pressures and alignment.
Review manufacturer battery warranty and capacity guidelines.
safety_warning: Range loss itself is not usually unsafe, but drivers should avoid planning trips at the edge of remaining range.

title: Hybrid Engine Revs High at Low Speed
symptom_short: Engine races or sounds loud even at low vehicle speeds
symptom_patterns: engine revs high but car slow

likely_causes.cause: Normal behavior of some eCVT-based hybrids under heavy acceleration
likely_causes.notes: Engine speed may not match road speed like traditional transmissions.

likely_causes.cause: Battery charge low so system relies heavily on engine

recommended_checks: Notice if behavior is mostly when accelerating uphill or with low battery.
Compare to owner's manual description of typical hybrid operation.
Check for warning lights if noise is accompanied by poor performance.
safety_warning: If loud engine operation is accompanied by warning lights or severe loss of power, the vehicle should be inspected.

title: Blower Fan Works Only on Highest Speed
symptom_short: HVAC fan only works on max speed

likely_causes.cause: Failed blower motor resistor or control module

recommended_checks: Test all blower speed positions.
Note if issue started suddenly or after moisture exposure.
Inspect resistor pack area for corrosion if accessible.
safety_warning: Limited blower control mainly affects comfort and defogging. In very humid or cold weather, poor defrost can affect visibility.

title: Musty or Moldy Smell When AC First Turns On
symptom_short: Musty odor from vents at AC startup

likely_causes.cause: Mold or bacteria growth on evaporator core due to moisture

recommended_checks: Run fan for a few minutes without AC before shutting vehicle off to dry the system.
Replace cabin air filter if dirty.
Use HVAC-specific cleaner sprayed into intake as directed.
safety_warning: While usually not immediately dangerous, prolonged exposure to moldy air can irritate sensitive occupants.

title: Power Window Moves Very Slowly or Gets Stuck
symptom_short: Power window slow, jerky, or stuck

likely_causes.cause: Dry or contaminated window guides and channels
Failing window regulator or motor

recommended_checks: Avoid forcing the switch repeatedly if glass barely moves.
Inspect rubber channels for debris or damage.
Consider silicone-safe lubricant on window guides.
safety_warning: Windows stuck open can be a security and weather issue, but usually not a driving safety risk unless they affect visibility.

title: Power Door Lock Works Intermittently
symptom_short: Door lock sometimes does not lock/unlock with remote or switch

likely_causes.cause: Weak door lock actuator in affected door
Broken or corroded wiring in door jamb flex harness

recommended_checks: Note which specific door fails most often.
Listen for faint clicking inside door when command is sent.
Check for other electrical issues in same door (window, mirror).
safety_warning: A door that fails to lock is a security risk and may be critical for child safety seats.

title: Push-Button Start Says Key Not Detected
symptom_short: Keyless system does not detect key for starting
symptom_patterns: have to hold key near button

likely_causes.cause: Weak key fob battery
Radio interference or antenna issue near keyless receiver

recommended_checks: Try starting with key placed in the backup location described in the manual.
Replace key fob battery if old.
Check if problem only occurs in certain parking locations (possible interference).
safety_warning: If 'key not detected' appears while driving, the vehicle usually continues running but may not restart after shutoff.

title: Front Collision or Radar Sensor Blocked
symptom_short: Collision warning or adaptive cruise temporarily unavailable

likely_causes.cause: Dirt, ice, snow, or stickers covering radar or camera area
Misaligned radar or camera after minor collision or windshield replacement

recommended_checks: Clean front emblem, bumper area, and windshield where sensors are located.
Note if warning appears mainly in heavy rain, fog, or snow.
After body or glass repair, ensure ADAS calibration was performed.
safety_warning: Do not rely on ADAS when a sensor-block message is active. Drive as if the assistance systems are not available.

title: Lane Keep Assist or Lane Departure Not Available
symptom_short: Lane-keeping system off or unavailable

likely_causes.cause: Camera unable to detect lane markings due to poor paint, darkness, or heavy rain
Dirty or obstructed windshield in camera area

recommended_checks: Clean exterior glass around the front camera.
Test on a well-marked highway in good daylight.
Check for warning messages that indicate a fault versus temporary condition.
safety_warning: Lane systems are driver aids only. Never rely on them to keep the lane if warning messages indicate they are unavailable.

title: Surging or Bucking at Steady Speed
symptom_short: Vehicle surges or bucks when cruising at steady speed

likely_causes.cause: Fuel delivery irregularities (pump, filter, or pressure regulator)
Ignition coil or plug breaking down under light load
Throttle body or EGR valve issues

recommended_checks: Note if problem happens only at certain speeds or when cruise control is on.
Check for recent misfire or fuel-system fault codes.
Observe if problem is worse on hills or with AC on.
safety_warning: Severe surging can affect control, especially on slippery roads. Reduce speed and avoid aggressive maneuvers.

title: Engine Stalls When Coming to a Stop
symptom_short: Engine dies when slowing or stopping
symptom_patterns: dies when coming to a light

likely_causes.cause: Dirty throttle body or idle air control issue
Torque converter clutch staying locked (automatic transmission)
Vacuum leak or inconsistent fuel delivery

recommended_checks: Note if stall happens only after highway driving or always.
Observe if RPM drops suddenly just before the stall.
Scan for transmission and engine fault codes.
safety_warning: Stalling while turning or in traffic can be dangerous. If frequent, have the vehicle inspected promptly.

title: Check Engine Light for Small Evap Leak (Loose Gas Cap)
symptom_short: Check-engine light with small leak evap code

likely_causes.cause: Loose or worn gas cap seal
Small leak in evap hoses or canister

recommended_checks: Tighten gas cap until it clicks several times.
Inspect cap seal for cracks or damage.
After tightening or replacing cap, drive several days to see if light clears.
safety_warning: Evap leaks rarely create driving issues but can cause failed emissions tests and fuel vapor release to the atmosphere.

title: Tires Wearing Heavily on Inside Edge
symptom_short: Inside edge of tires worn faster than rest

likely_causes.cause: Incorrect camber or toe alignment
Worn suspension bushings or ball joints

recommended_checks: Run hand across tread to feel for sharp edges or cupping.
Check all four tires; front and rear may show different patterns.
Schedule alignment and suspension inspection before installing new tires.
safety_warning: Severe edge wear can expose cords and risk blowout even when the rest of the tread looks acceptable.

title: Constant Metallic Scraping from One Wheel
symptom_short: Metal scraping sound that changes with speed

likely_causes.cause: Bent or rusted backing plate touching rotor
Small stone caught between rotor and shield

recommended_checks: Note if sound changes when turning slightly left or right.
Inspect inside of wheel and brake area with light if safe.
Have brake assembly checked if noise persists.
safety_warning: While often minor, some scraping noises can mask more serious brake issues and should not be ignored.

title: One Headlight Out But Others OK
symptom_short: Single headlight not working

likely_causes.cause: Burned-out bulb or LED module failure
Connector or wiring corrosion at that headlamp

recommended_checks: Confirm high beam vs low beam operation on each side.
Inspect connector behind headlamp (if accessible) for corrosion.
For LED systems, check for TSBs (technical bulletins) related to early failure.
safety_warning: Driving with one headlight reduces visibility and can confuse other drivers. Repair as soon as feasible.

title: Water or Condensation Inside Tail Lamp
symptom_short: Water or heavy fog inside rear light cluster

likely_causes.cause: Failed lamp housing seal or crack in lens

recommended_checks: Look for visible cracks or gaps around lamp edges.
Check if moisture appears mainly after rain or car wash.
Ensure bulbs and sockets are not corroded.
safety_warning: Water intrusion can corrode contacts and eventually cause brake or signal light failure, which is a safety issue.

title: EV Not Charging Properly at Home
symptom_short: EV fails to start or complete home charging session

likely_causes.cause: Fault or misconfiguration in home EVSE (wall charger) or outlet
Charge port or cable contamination (dirt, corrosion, ice)
Vehicle charge settings (schedule, limit) not matching user expectation

recommended_checks: Check for warning lights or messages on both car and charger.
Test charging at a different location (public station) if possible.
Inspect charge port and connector for debris or signs of damage.
safety_warning: Do not attempt to repair high-voltage or EVSE wiring yourself. Use qualified electricians and follow local electrical codes.

title: Alternator AC Ripple Damaging Electronics
symptom_short: Lights flicker, modules reset, battery light may flicker

likely_causes.cause: Alternator diode failure causing high AC ripple on DC system
likely_causes.notes: AC ripple above ~0.3V can damage ECUs, TCMs, BCMs, coils and sensors.

likely_causes.cause: Loose alternator ground or power cable adding noise

recommended_checks: Measure alternator AC ripple with a meter set to AC volts (should be typically under 0.05–0.1V).
Check alternator output cable and grounds for corrosion or loose connections.
Inspect charging system wiring for damaged insulation or poor repairs.
safety_warning: Driving with high AC ripple can slowly destroy sensitive electronics and ignition components; repair as soon as possible.

title: Advanced Parasitic Draw — Battery Dies Overnight
symptom_short: Battery repeatedly dead after parking for hours

likely_causes.cause: Module or accessory staying awake (stuck relay, aftermarket alarm, audio amp, telematics unit)
Body control module not entering sleep mode due to network or sensor issue
Old battery that can no longer tolerate normal small draws

recommended_checks: Measure key-off current draw after modules should be asleep (typically < 50 mA on most vehicles).
Pull fuses one by one while monitoring draw to isolate the problematic circuit.
Check trunk, glovebox, and courtesy lights to ensure they fully turn off.
Load-test the battery to confirm it can still hold a charge.
safety_warning: High parasitic draw can destroy a new battery in days and leave the driver stranded repeatedly.

title: CAN Bus Network Failure — Multiple Modules Affected
symptom_short: Multiple warning lights, communication errors, random failures
symptom_patterns: many lights on dash at once

likely_causes.cause: CAN high or CAN low wire shorted to ground or power
Failed module pulling down the CAN network
Water intrusion or corrosion in harness connectors or junction blocks

recommended_checks: Measure CAN bus resistance with the system powered down — should be ~60 ohms across CAN high and CAN low.
Use wiring diagrams to locate bus splice points and check for corrosion or water.
Unplug suspect modules one by one while monitoring network behavior to find the module pulling the bus down.
safety_warning: CAN bus failures can disable ABS, stability control, airbags, transmission control and other critical systems, severely affecting safety.

title: ECU Power Loss on Bumps — Random Engine Cut Out
symptom_short: Engine shuts off randomly, often over bumps, then restarts
symptom_patterns: engine cuts out randomly and comes back
loss of power like key turned off

likely_causes.cause: Loose ECU power or ground connector/terminal
Failing main relay or ECM relay with heat-related or vibration-related failure
Loose battery or main power cable feeding ECU/under-hood fuse box

recommended_checks: With engine idling in a safe area, gently tap ECU and fuse box to see if engine stumbles.
Check voltage drop across ECU grounds with engine running (should be very low, ideally < 0.1V).
Inspect connectors for corrosion, bent pins, or poor terminal tension.
safety_warning: Sudden engine shutdown at speed causes loss of power steering and brake assist, which is extremely dangerous; issue must be addressed immediately.

title: Critical Engine/Chassis Ground Strap Failure
symptom_short: Random electrical problems and sensor errors across systems
symptom_patterns: dim lights and weird electrical issues
multiple sensor codes with no pattern

likely_causes.cause: Corroded or broken ground strap between engine and chassis
Loose or contaminated battery negative terminal

recommended_checks: Measure resistance between engine block and battery negative; it should be very low.
Inspect ground straps visually for broken strands, corrosion, or missing bolts.
Perform voltage drop tests on ground circuits during cranking and with heavy loads on.
safety_warning: Bad grounds can cause ECU damage, random shutdowns, and unpredictable behavior of safety systems.

title: Crankshaft/Camshaft Correlation Error — Timing Concern
symptom_short: Hard starting, rough idle, correlation codes like P0016–P0017

likely_causes.cause: Timing chain stretch or wear causing cam and crank to drift out of spec
likely_causes.notes: Common on engines with extended oil change intervals.

likely_causes.cause: Failed or weak camshaft or crankshaft position sensor

recommended_checks: Check live data for cam/crank synchronization at different RPMs.
Use scan tool or scope to inspect cam and crank signal relationship.
Inspect mechanical timing marks and chain or belt slack where access allows.
safety_warning: Driving with correlation issues can lead to severe engine damage if timing jumps further, especially on interference engines.

title: Fuel Pump Control Module (FPDM) Failure
symptom_short: Long crank, stalls, power loss, unstable fuel pressure

likely_causes.cause: Fuel pump control module overheating or failing internally
Corroded ground or wiring to the fuel pump module

recommended_checks: Monitor fuel pressure while driving and note drops during hesitation.
Tap the fuel pump module lightly (if accessible) to see if symptom changes.
Inspect module housing and connectors for moisture or corrosion.
safety_warning: Sudden fuel pressure loss can cause the engine to stall in traffic; treat as a safety-critical issue.

title: High-Pressure Fuel System Fault (GDI Engines)
symptom_short: Loss of power at high RPM/load, misfires, long crank
symptom_patterns: gdi engine low power under boost

likely_causes.cause: Failing high-pressure fuel pump (HPFP)
likely_causes.notes: Some HPFP failures shed metal particles that contaminate the entire system.

likely_causes.cause: Faulty high-pressure fuel rail sensor

recommended_checks: Monitor commanded vs actual fuel rail pressure under load.
Inspect fuel for metallic debris where applicable.
Perform injector balance or leak-down tests as recommended by manufacturer.
safety_warning: Low rail pressure on GDI engines can cause lean operation and potential engine damage; do not ignore under-load misfire or power loss.

title: Slow Oxygen Sensor Response — Fuel Trim Issues
symptom_short: Poor fuel economy, unstable idle, fluctuating trims
symptom_patterns: poor mpg with no obvious reason

likely_causes.cause: Aging oxygen sensor with slow switching response
Small exhaust leak before O2 sensor causing false readings

recommended_checks: View upstream O2 sensor waveform; healthy sensors switch rapidly between rich and lean.
Inspect exhaust manifold and flex sections for leaks.
Check long-term fuel trims for chronic rich or lean conditions.
safety_warning: Slow O2 response can over time stress the catalytic converter and increase emissions and fuel consumption.

title: False Knock Detection — Power Reduced
symptom_short: Engine power reduced, timing pulled, no real knock
symptom_patterns: knock sensor code but no noise

likely_causes.cause: Loose knock sensor or damaged wiring causing noise pickup
Excessive engine vibration or mounts transmitting noise as knock
Carbon buildup causing real but low-level knock even with normal driving

recommended_checks: Verify knock sensor torque to factory spec.
Inspect engine mounts and accessories for abnormal vibration.
Review timing advance and knock retard data while driving.
safety_warning: While false knock mostly reduces performance, ignoring real knock can be dangerous for the engine. Confirm root cause before aggressive driving.

title: MAF/Load Conflict — Hesitation and Stalling
symptom_short: Hesitation, stalling at idle, inconsistent throttle response
symptom_patterns: maf sensor code with vacuum leak
car stalls when stopping after cleaning maf
load reading does not match reality

likely_causes.cause: Dirty or failing mass airflow (MAF) sensor
Vacuum leak causing airflow not to match MAF reading
Incorrect aftermarket air intake or oiled filter contaminating sensor

recommended_checks: Check fuel trims (high positive trims often indicate vacuum leak).
Inspect intake boots and PCV hoses for cracks or loose clamps.
Clean MAF sensor only with appropriate MAF cleaner; avoid touching the element.
safety_warning: Serious lean conditions from MAF/vacuum issues can cause misfire and overheating of engine components and catalytic converters.

title: Body Control Module (BCM) Fault — Random Body Electrical Issues
symptom_short: Random window, lock, light, wiper or chime issues
symptom_patterns: windows and locks act on their own
lights flicker but charging system ok

likely_causes.cause: Internal BCM failure due to solder cracks or component damage
Water intrusion into BCM or connectors
Broken wires in door or pillar harness affecting BCM inputs

recommended_checks: Scan BCM for multiple unrelated input/output fault codes.
Inspect under-dash and kick panel areas for moisture or corrosion.
Check door boot wiring for broken conductors especially on high-use doors.
safety_warning: BCM failure can in some vehicles affect immobilizer, lighting, wipers and even starting; it can be both a safety and security issue.

title: EVAP System Large Leak — Hard Start After Refuel
symptom_short: Check-engine light with EVAP large leak and rough start after fueling

likely_causes.cause: EVAP purge valve stuck open allowing raw vapor into intake
Loose, missing, or damaged gas cap
Cracked EVAP hoses or charcoal canister

recommended_checks: Ensure gas cap is tight and seal in good condition.
Perform EVAP smoke test to locate large leaks.
Test purge valve operation with scan tool or vacuum source.
safety_warning: EVAP leaks are rarely an immediate driving hazard but can cause rough running, failed emissions tests, and increased fuel vapor emissions.

title: High-Voltage Isolation Fault on Hybrid/EV
symptom_short: High-voltage isolation or "Service HV system" warning

likely_causes.cause: Moisture or coolant intrusion into high-voltage components or wiring
likely_causes.notes: Often affects inverters, junction boxes, battery packs, or cooling plates.

likely_causes.cause: Damaged orange high-voltage cable insulation or chafed wiring to chassis

recommended_checks: Do NOT touch orange high-voltage components or wiring.
Have an HV-qualified technician measure insulation resistance to ground.
Check for service bulletins related to coolant leakage into HV components.
safety_warning: High-voltage isolation faults are extremely dangerous; only HV-certified personnel should diagnose and repair them.

title: Electrical Burning Smell Inside Cabin
symptom_short: Strong burning plastic or electrical odor inside the car

likely_causes.cause: Overheated wiring, connector, or blower-motor resistor under dash
likely_causes.notes: Often related to HVAC fan speeds or accessory loads.

likely_causes.cause: Short circuit in seat heaters, window circuits, or steering column wiring

recommended_checks: Immediately turn off non-essential electrical accessories including seat heaters, HVAC, and chargers.
Look (from a safe distance) for visible smoke or melted plastics.
Have wiring inspected urgently; do not continue operating circuits that trigger the smell.
safety_warning: Strong electrical burning smell or visible smoke can precede an interior fire; stop the vehicle safely, shut it off, and exit if the smell is intense.

title: Main Fuse or High-Current Fuse Blows Repeatedly
symptom_short: Main or large fuse blows as soon as it is replaced
symptom_patterns: replace fuse and it blows again immediately

likely_causes.cause: Direct short to ground in a high-current circuit (starter, alternator, or main power feed)

recommended_checks: Do NOT install a larger fuse than specified; this is extremely unsafe.
Determine which systems lose power when the fuse blows (charging, interior power, etc.).
Use a current-limited power supply and proper diagnostic tools to locate the short rather than burning more fuses.
safety_warning: High-current shorts can overheat wiring and start a fire; the vehicle should not be driven until the fault is repaired.
